properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall amounts of 40 to 50 millimetres are expected over these areas beginning this evening. Precipitation will change over to snow on Tuesday. ### Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-24T01:50:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-23T09:51:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4097043421.2020
Area: Minganie, Natashquan, Chevery
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A total of 15 to 20 centimetres of snow is expected beginning overnight tonight. This snow will be accompanied by high northwesterly winds reaching up to 90 kilometres per hour as well as blowing snow. Visibility will suddenly be reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-24T01:50:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-23T09:51:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3315833435.2020
Area: Grande-Vallée area, Sainte-Anne-des-Monts area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A few hours of freezing precipitation is expected beginning this morning. The freezing precipitation will change to rain later this afternoon as temperatures will rise above the freezing mark. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-23T21:29:45-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Warning of potential breaking sea conditions and overwash issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec Area on 2020-11-23. Higher than normal water levels and large waves are expected near the coast in the concerned areas. An intense low pressure system approaching from New England will give strong winds over the areas listed below. The combination of these winds and the current run of medium-amplitude tidal ranges may produce minor breaking sea conditions along the coast near the following localities, on the dates and at the times specified (Eastern Standard Time). Forillon Park - Gaspé - Percé: 2020-11-23, from 7:30 P.M. to 10:30 P.M. New-Carlisle - Chandler: 2020-11-23, from 07:30 PM to 10:30 PM. Anticosti: 2020-11-23, from 07:30 PM to 10:30 PM. Natashquan: 2020-11-23, from 04:00 PM to 07:30 PM. ### Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-24T04:59:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-23T13:04:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2848752542.2020
Area: Chandler area, New Carlisle - Port-Daniel area, Forillon National Park - Gaspé area, Percé area, Natashquan, Anticosti
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall tonight. Snow will continue tonight. 5 to 10 cm of accumulation is expected before the snow tapers off early Monday morning. Travel is expected to be impacted. Motorists should be prepared for winter weather driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall tonight. Snow, at times heavy, will continue into tonight. Snowfall amounts of 15 to 20 cm are expected by the time the snow tapers off Monday morning. This heavy snow is due to a strengthening low pressure system that will track northeastward across the lower Great Lakes tonight. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: southeasterly 80 km/h, except 100 along parts of the coast and over exposed areas. Locations: southern Newfoundland from Channel-Port aux Basques to the Burin Peninsula. Time span: overnight tonight until Tuesday morning. Remarks: Strong southeasterly winds gusting up to 100 km/h will develop in the Channel-Port aux Basques area overnight tonight. The strong winds will spread eastwards Tuesday morning. Winds over all regions will shift to strong westerlies with gusts near 80 km/h Tuesday morning. The westerlies may approach or reach warning criteria Tuesday night in the Channel-Port aux Basques area. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-24T05:47:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-23T13:48:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1418521444.2020
Area: Burin Peninsula, Connaigre, Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, rain, and strong winds expected. Total snowfall: near 10 cm. Total rainfall: up to 35 mm, with the greatest amounts expected from Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair. Maximum wind gusts: southeasterly 80 km/h on Tuesday becoming northwesterly up to 100 km/h Tuesday night. Locations: southeastern Labrador. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, is expected to develop this evening before changing to rain overnight tonight. The rain will end late in the day Tuesday and strong northwesterly winds will develop Tuesday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Total snowfall: widespread 50 to 70 cm with near 80 cm possible for Upper Lake Melville. Maximum wind gusts: northerly up to 90 km/h on Tuesday. Locations: central Labrador including Upper Lake Melville. Time span: tonight through Tuesday evening. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, is expected to develop this evening and continue through the day on Tuesday. Strong northerly winds will develop early Tuesday resulting in widespread blowing snow. Conditions will improve late on Tuesday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-24T06:40:13-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A deep low pressure system will approach over the Gulf of Alaska late today and combine with an Arctic ridge over the Northwest Territories to give rise to strong east winds of 70 km/h gusting to 90 near the Richardson Mountains. These strong winds will cause poor visibility in blowing snow and wind chill values near minus 25. Blizzard conditions will begin late this afternoon and then end overnight. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. A Pacific frontal system will spread snow to Pine Pass by early this evening. The snow will become heavy at times overnight and early Tuesday resulting in accumulations of up to 20 cm. The snow will end by late Tuesday morning as the front moves south of the region. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
